messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 44 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Provably Approximated ICP

Paper Abstract: Abstract The goal of the alignment problem is to align a (given) point cloud P={p1,⋯,pn}𝑃subscript𝑝1⋯subscript𝑝𝑛P=\{p_{1},\cdots,p_{n}\} to another (observed) point cloud Q={q1,⋯,qn}𝑄subscript𝑞1⋯subscript𝑞𝑛Q=\{q_{1},\cdots,q_{n}\}. That is, to compute a rotation matrix R∈ℝ3×3𝑅superscriptℝ33R\in\mathbb{R}^{3\times 3} and a translation vector t∈ℝ3𝑡superscriptℝ3t\in\mathbb{R}^{3} that minimize the sum of paired distances ∑i=1nD​(R​pi−t,qi)superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛𝐷𝑅subscript𝑝𝑖𝑡subscript𝑞𝑖\sum_{i=1}^{n}D(Rp_{i}-t,q_{i}) for some distance function D𝐷D. A harder version is the registration problem, where the correspondence is unknown, and the minimum is also over all possible correspondence functions from P𝑃P to Q𝑄Q. Heuristics such as the Iterative Closest Point (ICP) algorithm and its variants were suggested for these problems, but none yield a provable non-trivial approximation for the global optimum. We prove that there always exists a “witness” set of 333 pairs in P×Q𝑃𝑄P\times Q that, via novel alignment algorithm, defines a constant factor approximation (in the worst case) to this global optimum. We then provide algorithms that recover this witness set and yield the first provable constant factor approximation for the: (i) alignment problem in O​(n)𝑂𝑛O(n) expected time, and (ii) registration problem in polynomial time. Such small witness sets exist for many variants including points in d𝑑d-dimensional space, outlier-resistant cost functions, and different correspondence types. Extensive experimental results on real and synthetic datasets show that our approximation constants are, in practice, close to 111, and up to x101010 times smaller than state-of-the-art algorithms.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 44 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 44"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Pointnetlk: Robust & efficient point cloud registration using pointnet",
        "Method for registration of 3-d shapes",
        "The normal distributions transform: A new approach to laser scan matching",
        "Object modelling by registration of multiple range images",
        "Open source code for all the algorithms presented in this paper",
        "Graph matching with a dual-step em algorithm",
        "A volumetric method for building complex models from range images",
        "Linearly converging quasi branch and bound algorithms for global rigid registration",
        "Data reduction for weighted and outlier-resistant clustering",
        "Designing and building parallel programs: concepts and tools for parallel software engineering",
        "3d simultaneous localization and modeling from stereo vision",
        "Singular value decomposition and least squares solutions",
        "Unsupervised learning of dense shape correspondence",
        "Robust point set registration using em-icp with information-theoretically optimal outlier handling",
        "Robust statistics",
        "On the problem of correspondence in range data and some inelastic uses for elastic nets",
        "Provable approximations for constrained lpsubscript𝑙𝑝l_{p} regression",
        "Aligning points to lines: Provable approximations",
        "A solution for the best rotation to relate two sets of vectors",
        "Fitting smooth surfaces to dense polygon meshes",
        "The hungarian method for the assignment problem",
        "Object recognition from local scale-invariant features",
        "A unified framework for alignment and correspondence",
        "Scan registration for autonomous mining vehicles using 3d-ndt",
        "Fully automatic registration of 3d point clouds",
        "A probabilistic approach to robust shape matching",
        "Point set registration: Coherent point drift",
        "Coresets for kinematic data: From theorems to real-time systems",
        "Kinectfusion: Real-time dense surface mapping and tracking",
        "Branch-and-bound methods for euclidean registration problems",
        "Motion capture systems",
        "A review of point cloud registration algorithms for mobile robotics",
        "Comparing icp variants on real-world data sets",
        "Cobe-coded beacons for localization, object tracking, and slam augmentation",
        "A robust point-matching algorithm for autoradiograph alignment",
        "A review of recent range image registration methods with accuracy evaluation",
        "Registration of 3d point clouds and meshes: A survey from rigid to nonrigid",
        "A correlation-based approach to robust point set registration",
        "Zippered polygon meshes from range images",
        "Motion systems",
        "Deep closest point: Learning representations for point cloud registration",
        "Statistical approaches to feature-based object recognition",
        "Real-time large-scale dense rgb-d slam with volumetric fusion",
        "Go-icp: A globally optimal solution to 3d icp point-set registration"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 44 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Provably Approximated ICP, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
